question: From 2003 to 2008 Tom Holland was responsible for what  ?

nodes.instruction: Identify who Tom Holland is that might have been responsible for something between 2003 to 2008. Retrieve all possible persons with the name 'Tom Holland'.
nodes.output:
Possible persons with the name 'Tom Holland' include:
1. Tom Holland, Democratic member of the Kansas Senate from 2009 to present, and member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008.
2. Tom Holland, founder of Apnalaya, a non-profit organization in Bombay.
3. Tom Holland, director of the 1996 film "Thinner" and the 2013 webseries "Twisted Tales."
4. Tom Holland, co-writer of the 1982 film "Class of 1984."

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about roles, projects, or responsibilities of each identified Tom Holland between 2003 and 2008.
nodes.output: Tom Holland, a Democratic member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008, was responsible for crafting and voting on legislation, helping to create a state budget, and providing legislative oversight over state agencies. In 2010, he ran for Governor of Kansas as the Democratic nominee but was defeated by Republican Sam Brownback.

nodes.instruction: Analyze the retrieved information to identify what each Tom Holland was responsible for between 2003 to 2008 and consolidate it into a clear list.
nodes.output:
- Crafted and voted on legislation as a Democratic member of the Kansas House of Representatives
- Helped to create a state budget
- Provided legislative oversight over state agencies

retrieved_passages:
Tom Holland (politician)
Tom Holland (born July 23, 1961) is a Democratic member of the Kansas Senate, representing the 3rd District since 2009. He was a member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008.

Kansas gubernatorial election, 2010
The 2010 Kansas gubernatorial election was held on November 2, 2010. Incumbent Governor Mark Parkinson, who assumed office when previous Governor Kathleen Sebelius was sworn in as the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services on April 28, 2009, declined to seek election to a full term. United States Senator Sam Brownback, who unsuccessfully ran for president in 2008, emerged as the Republican nominee, facing off against Democratic State Senator Tom Holland, who was unopposed for his party's nomination. Owing to the large amount of popularity that he had accumulated during his tenure in the United States Senate, Brownback defeated Holland in a landslide to become the 46th Governor of Kansas.

Kansas House of Representatives
The Kansas House of Representatives is the lower house of the legislature of the U.S. state of Kansas. Composed of 125 state representatives from districts with roughly equal populations of at least 19,000, its members are responsible for crafting and voting on legislation, helping to create a state budget, and legislative oversight over state agencies.

Tom Foley
Thomas Stephen Foley, KBE (March 6, 1929 – October 18, 2013) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 49th Speaker of the United States House of Representatives from 1989 to 1995. A member of the Democratic Party Foley represented Washington's 5th congressional district as from 1965 to 1995. Foley was the first Speaker of the House since 1862 to be defeated in a re-election campaign.

Bill Devlin
William R. Devlin (born c. 1947) is an American politician in the state of North Dakota. He is a member of the North Dakota House of Representatives, representing the 23rd district. A Republican, he was first elected in 2010 and also served from 1997 to 2005. He is an alumnus of Mayville State College and former newspaper publisher. Devlin is a former president of the North Dakota Newspaper Association. During his first stint in the House of Representatives, he was the Majority Party Caucus Leader for one year in 1999. He was named Speaker of the North Dakota House of Representatives in 2013. On September 10, 2013 he met with Jack J. C. Yang of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Kansas City.

Sara Steelman
Sara G. Steelman (born 1946 in Wichita, Kansas) of Indiana, Pennsylvania, American biologist and politician, served seven terms as a Democratic member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 1991 until 2002. Steelman is married to John Henry Steelman, a mathematics professor at Indiana University. She is a 1963 graduate of Southeast High School in Wichita, Kansas. She graduated with a degree in Zoology from the University of Chicago in 1967 and earned a Ph.D. in behavioural genetics from Stanford University in 1976. She moved to Indiana in 1986 when her husband joined the faculty at Indiana University of Pennsylvania.

Tom Rasmussen
Tom Rasmussen is a retired member of the Seattle City Council, first elected in 2003. Between September 2004 and December 2007 he was chair of the Housing, Human Services & Health Committee, vice chair of the Urban Development & Planning Committee, and a member of the Transportation Committee. On January 7, 2008 Tom was sworn in for his second term on City Council. From January 2008 through December 2009, he was chair of the Parks & Seattle Center Committee, the vice chair of the Culture, Civil Rights, Health and Personnel Committee, and the Labor Policy Committee. He was also chair of the Transportation Committee, vice chair of the Economic Resiliency and Regional Relations, and a member of Parks and Seattle Center Committee.

Massachusetts House of Representatives
The Massachusetts House of Representatives is the lower house of the Massachusetts General Court, the state legislature of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. It is composed of 160 members elected from 12 counties each divided into single-member electoral districts across the Commonwealth. The House of Representatives convenes at the Massachusetts State House in Boston.

Apnalaya
Apnalaya, "Our Space" in English, is a non-profit organization, founded in 1973 by Tom Holland, who was then the Australian Consul General in Bombay. At that time it was called Holland Welfare Centre, which was a day care centre for labourer's children in Nariman Point, the place where National Centre for the Performing Arts (NCPA) stands today.

Here's the Thing
Here's the Thing is a public radio show and podcast interview series hosted by actor Alec Baldwin. On October 24, 2011, New York City's WNYC released the first episode of Baldwin's podcast, a series of interviews with public figures including artists, policy makers and performers. "Here's the Thing" was developed for Baldwin by Lu Olkowski, Trey Kay, Kathy Russo and Emily Botein.

Thinner (film)
Thinner (marketed as Stephen King's Thinner) is a 1996 American body horror film directed by Tom Holland and written by Michael McDowell and Holland. The film is based on the Stephen King novel of the same name and stars Robert John Burke, Joe Mantegna, Lucinda Jenney, Michael Constantine, Kari Wührer and Bethany Joy Lenz.

Twisted Tales (web series)
Twisted Tales (also known as Tom Holland’s Twisted Tales) is a 2013 webseries that was written and directed by American director Tom Holland. The series was released in late 2013 through Fearnet's website and was released onto DVD on March 18, 2014 through Image Entertainment.

Class of 1984
Class of 1984 is a 1982 Canadian-American action crime thriller film directed by Mark Lester and co-written by Tom Holland and John Saxton based on a story by Holland. The film stars Perry King, Merrie Lynn Ross, Timothy Van Patten, Stefan Arngrim, Michael J. Fox (credited as Michael Fox in an early role shortly before his breakthrough on the TV series "Family Ties"), and Roddy McDowall.

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about roles, projects, or responsibilities of each identified Tom Holland between 2003 and 2008.
nodes.output: Tom Holland, a Democratic member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008, was involved in legislative responsibilities such as crafting and voting on legislation, creating a state budget, and providing legislative oversight over state agencies. In 2010, he ran for the position of Governor of Kansas but was defeated by Sam Brownback. His role as a member of the Kansas House of Representatives involved representing the 3rd District and participating in the political processes of the state.

nodes.instruction: Analyze the retrieved information to identify what each Tom Holland was responsible for between 2003 to 2008 and consolidate it into a clear list.
nodes.output:
- Tom Holland served as a Democratic member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008
- He was involved in crafting and voting on legislation
- He participated in creating a state budget
- He provided legislative oversight over state agencies
- He represented the 3rd District in Kansas
- In 2010, he ran for the position of Governor of Kansas but was defeated by Sam Brownback

question: From 2003 to 2008 Tom Holland was responsible for what  ?

nodes.instruction: Identify who Tom Holland is that might have been responsible for something between 2003 to 2008. Retrieve all possible persons with the name 'Tom Holland'.
nodes.output:
Possible persons with the name 'Tom Holland' include:
1. Tom Holland, a Democratic member of the Kansas Senate, who served in the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008.
2. Tom Holland, the Australian Consul General in Bombay who founded the non-profit organization Apnalaya in 1973.
3. Tom Holland, the American director who directed the film "Thinner" in 1996 and the web series "Twisted Tales" in 2013.
4. Tom Holland, who co-wrote the story for the 1982 film "Class of 1984."

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about roles, projects, or responsibilities of each identified Tom Holland between 2003 and 2008.
nodes.output:
Tom Holland (politician) served as a member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008. He then went on to run for Governor of Kansas in the 2010 election but was defeated by Sam Brownback.

Tom Holland (director) directed the film "Thinner" in 1996 and the web series "Twisted Tales" in 2013.

Tom Holland (writer) co-wrote the 1982 film "Class of 1984" and was involved in creating the American drama series "Nip/Tuck," which aired from 2003 to 2010.

Tom Holland (founder) established the non-profit organization Apnalaya in 1973, originally named Holland Welfare Centre, to provide daycare for laborer's children in Bombay.

nodes.instruction: Analyze the retrieved information to identify what each Tom Holland was responsible for between 2003 to 2008 and consolidate it into a clear list.
nodes.output:
- Tom Holland (politician) served as a member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008 and ran for Governor of Kansas in the 2010 election.
- Tom Holland (director) directed the film "Thinner" in 1996 and the web series "Twisted Tales" in 2013.
- Tom Holland (writer) co-wrote the 1982 film "Class of 1984" and was involved in creating the American drama series "Nip/Tuck," which aired from 2003 to 2010.
- Tom Holland (founder) established the non-profit organization Apnalaya in 1973, originally named Holland Welfare Centre, to provide daycare for laborer's children in Bombay.

List of Nip/Tuck episodes
"Nip/Tuck" is an American drama created by Ryan Murphy, which aired on FX in the United States between 2003 and 2010. The series focuses on McNamara/Troy, a plastic surgery practice, and follows its founders, Sean McNamara and Christian Troy (portrayed by Dylan Walsh and Julian McMahon). Each episode typically involves the cosmetic procedures of one or more patients, and also features the personal and professional lives of its main cast.

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about roles, projects, or responsibilities of each identified Tom Holland between 2003 and 2008.
nodes.output: Tom Holland, the politician, served as a member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008. During this time, he was responsible for crafting and voting on legislation, helping to create a state budget, and providing legislative oversight over state agencies. In 2010, he ran for Governor of Kansas as the Democratic nominee but was defeated by Republican Sam Brownback.

retrieved_passages:
Tom Holland (politician)
Tom Holland (born July 23, 1961) is a Democratic member of the Kansas Senate, representing the 3rd District since 2009. He was a member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008.

Kansas gubernatorial election, 2010
The 2010 Kansas gubernatorial election was held on November 2, 2010. Incumbent Governor Mark Parkinson, who assumed office when previous Governor Kathleen Sebelius was sworn in as the United States Secretary of Health and Human Services on April 28, 2009, declined to seek election to a full term. United States Senator Sam Brownback, who unsuccessfully ran for president in 2008, emerged as the Republican nominee, facing off against Democratic State Senator Tom Holland, who was unopposed for his party's nomination. Owing to the large amount of popularity that he had accumulated during his tenure in the United States Senate, Brownback defeated Holland in a landslide to become the 46th Governor of Kansas.

Kansas House of Representatives
The Kansas House of Representatives is the lower house of the legislature of the U.S. state of Kansas. Composed of 125 state representatives from districts with roughly equal populations of at least 19,000, its members are responsible for crafting and voting on legislation, helping to create a state budget, and legislative oversight over state agencies.

Tom Foley
Thomas Stephen Foley, KBE (March 6, 1929 – October 18, 2013) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 49th Speaker of the United States House of Representatives from 1989 to 1995. A member of the Democratic Party Foley represented Washington's 5th congressional district as from 1965 to 1995. Foley was the first Speaker of the House since 1862 to be defeated in a re-election campaign.

Edwin H. Lothrop
Edwin H. Lothrop was a politician from Michigan who served in the Michigan House of Representatives both prior to and after statehood, and who served as Speaker of the House during the 9th Legislature (coincidentally, as the 9th Speaker).

Bill Devlin
William R. Devlin (born c. 1947) is an American politician in the state of North Dakota. He is a member of the North Dakota House of Representatives, representing the 23rd district. A Republican, he was first elected in 2010 and also served from 1997 to 2005. He is an alumnus of Mayville State College and former newspaper publisher. Devlin is a former president of the North Dakota Newspaper Association. During his first stint in the House of Representatives, he was the Majority Party Caucus Leader for one year in 1999. He was named Speaker of the North Dakota House of Representatives in 2013. On September 10, 2013 he met with Jack J. C. Yang of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Kansas City.

Theodore M. Pomeroy
Theodore Medad Pomeroy (December 31, 1824 – March 23, 1905) was an American businessman and politician from New York who served as the 26th Speaker of the United States House of Representatives from March 3, 1869, to March 4, 1869, the shortest American speakership term in history. He represented New York's 24th congressional district in the United States House of Representatives from 1861 to 1869. He also served as the mayor of Auburn, New York, from 1875 to 1876, and in the New York State Senate from 1878 to 1879.

Sara Steelman
Sara G. Steelman (born 1946 in Wichita, Kansas) of Indiana, Pennsylvania, American biologist and politician, served seven terms as a Democratic member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives from 1991 until 2002. Steelman is married to John Henry Steelman, a mathematics professor at Indiana University. She is a 1963 graduate of Southeast High School in Wichita, Kansas. She graduated with a degree in Zoology from the University of Chicago in 1967 and earned a Ph.D. in behavioural genetics from Stanford University in 1976. She moved to Indiana in 1986 when her husband joined the faculty at Indiana University of Pennsylvania.

Tom Rasmussen
Tom Rasmussen is a retired member of the Seattle City Council, first elected in 2003. Between September 2004 and December 2007 he was chair of the Housing, Human Services & Health Committee, vice chair of the Urban Development & Planning Committee, and a member of the Transportation Committee. On January 7, 2008 Tom was sworn in for his second term on City Council. From January 2008 through December 2009, he was chair of the Parks & Seattle Center Committee, the vice chair of the Culture, Civil Rights, Health and Personnel Committee, and the Labor Policy Committee. He was also chair of the Transportation Committee, vice chair of the Economic Resiliency and Regional Relations, and a member of Parks and Seattle Center Committee.

Apnalaya
Apnalaya, "Our Space" in English, is a non-profit organization, founded in 1973 by Tom Holland, who was then the Australian Consul General in Bombay. At that time it was called Holland Welfare Centre, which was a day care centre for labourer's children in Nariman Point, the place where National Centre for the Performing Arts (NCPA) stands today.

Here's the Thing
Here's the Thing is a public radio show and podcast interview series hosted by actor Alec Baldwin. On October 24, 2011, New York City's WNYC released the first episode of Baldwin's podcast, a series of interviews with public figures including artists, policy makers and performers. "Here's the Thing" was developed for Baldwin by Lu Olkowski, Trey Kay, Kathy Russo and Emily Botein.

Thinner (film)
Thinner (marketed as Stephen King's Thinner) is a 1996 American body horror film directed by Tom Holland and written by Michael McDowell and Holland. The film is based on the Stephen King novel of the same name and stars Robert John Burke, Joe Mantegna, Lucinda Jenney, Michael Constantine, Kari Wührer and Bethany Joy Lenz.

Twisted Tales (web series)
Twisted Tales (also known as Tom Holland’s Twisted Tales) is a 2013 webseries that was written and directed by American director Tom Holland. The series was released in late 2013 through Fearnet's website and was released onto DVD on March 18, 2014 through Image Entertainment.

Class of 1984
Class of 1984 is a 1982 Canadian-American action crime thriller film directed by Mark Lester and co-written by Tom Holland and John Saxton based on a story by Holland. The film stars Perry King, Merrie Lynn Ross, Timothy Van Patten, Stefan Arngrim, Michael J. Fox (credited as Michael Fox in an early role shortly before his breakthrough on the TV series "Family Ties"), and Roddy McDowall.

3. Tom Holland, the American director who directed the film "Thinner" in 1996 and the web series "Twisted Tales" in 2013.
4. Tom Holland, who co-wrote the story for the 1982 film "Class of 1984."

nodes.instruction: Retrieve information about roles, projects, or responsibilities of each identified Tom Holland between 2003 and 2008.
nodes.output:
Tom Holland (politician) served as a member of the Kansas House of Representatives from 2003 to 2008. He then went on to run for Governor of Kansas in the 2010 election but was defeated by Sam Brownback.

Tom Holland (director) directed the film "Thinner" in 1996 and the web series "Twisted Tales" in 2013.

Tom Holland (writer) co-wrote the 1982 film "Class of 1984" and was involved in creating the American drama series "Nip/Tuck," which aired from 2003 to 2010.

Tom Holland (founder) established the non-profit organization Apnalaya in 1973, originally named Holland Welfare Centre, which provided daycare for laborer's children in Bombay.

Here's the Thing

Thinner (film)
Thinner (marketed as Stephen King's Thinner) is a 1996 American body horror film directed by Tom Holland and written by Michael McDowell and Holland. The film is based on the Stephen King novel of the same name and stars Robert John Burke, Joe Mantegna, Lucinda Jenney, Michael Constantine, Kari Wührer and Bethany Joy Lenz.

Twisted Tales (web series)
Twisted Tales (also known as Tom Holland’s Twisted Tales) is a 2013 webseries that was written and directed by American director Tom Holland. The series was released in late 2013 through Fearnet's website and was released onto DVD on March 18, 2014 through Image Entertainment.

Class of 1984
Class of 1984 is a 1982 Canadian-American action crime thriller film directed by Mark Lester and co-written by Tom Holland and John Saxton based on a story by Holland. The film stars Perry King, Merrie Lynn Ross, Timothy Van Patten, Stefan Arngrim, Michael J. Fox (credited as Michael Fox in an early role shortly before his breakthrough on the TV series "Family Ties"), and Roddy McDowall.

List of Nip/Tuck episodes
"Nip/Tuck" is an American drama created by Ryan Murphy, which aired on FX in the United States between 2003 and 2010. The series focuses on McNamara/Troy, a plastic surgery practice, and follows its founders, Sean McNamara and Christian Troy (portrayed by Dylan Walsh and Julian McMahon). Each episode typically involves the cosmetic procedures of one or more patients, and also features the personal and professional lives of its main cast.
